Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 56-year-old patient is being treated with oral amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia. The plasma clearance of the drug is calculated as 15.0 L/h. Oral bioavailability of the drug is 75%. Sensitivity analysis of a sputum culture shows a minimal inhibitory concentration of 1 μg/mL for the causative pathogen. The target plasma concentration is 2 mg/L. If the drug is administered twice per day, which of the following dosages should be administered at each dosing interval to maintain a steady state?
(A) 270 mg (B) 480 mg (C) 240 mg (D) 540 mg

question: Q: A 56-year-old patient is being treated with oral amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia. The plasma clearance of the drug is calculated as 15.0 L/h. Oral bioavailability of the drug is 75%. Sensitivity analysis of a sputum culture shows a minimal inhibitory concentration of 1 μg/mL for the causative pathogen. The target plasma concentration is 2 mg/L. If the drug is administered twice per day, which of the following dosages should be administered at each dosing interval to maintain a steady state?
outputs:
The patient is being treated with oral amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia. The plasma clearance of the drug is calculated as 15.0 L/h. Oral bioavailability of the drug is 75%. Sensitivity analysis of a sputum culture shows a minimal inhibitory concentration of 1 μg/mL for the causative pathogen. The target plasma concentration is 2 mg/L. The steady-state plasma concentration can be calculated using the equation Css = Clot / Clr, where Css is the steady-state plasma concentration, Clot is the loading dose, and Clr is the plasma clearance. To maintain a steady state, the drug must be administered at a dose that replaces the amount cleared by the body. The plasma clearance is 15.0 L/h, so the drug must be administered at a dose that replaces 15.0 L/h of the drug. The loading dose can be calculated using the equation Clot = Css / (1 - e^(-Clr/2))). The answer is (B).

A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and obesity. She has a sudden-onset severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. Her blood pressure is 188/108 mm Hg. A non-contrast head CT scan shows a 6-mm left parietal intracerebral hemorrhage. The patient has hypertensive emergency. The most appropriate next step in management is to lower the blood pressure acutely to reduce the risk of further bleeding. The answer is (D).

Q: A 5-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician’s office by his parents after they noticed blood in his urine. Ketones Negative
RBCs 1-2/hpf

Q: A 5-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician’s office by his parents after they noticed blood in his urine. The child has been complaining of difficulty in passing urine and has lower abdominal pain. He seems more bloated than usual. On some occasions, he starts crying while passing urine, primarily because of a burning sensation. A urinalysis is performed, and the results are as follows:
Urine pH 6.2
Urine specific gravity 1.010
Glucose Negative
Ketones Negative
RBCs 1-2/hpf
WBCs 0-1/hpf
Casts 2-3/hpf
The pediatrician believes the boy has a bladder infection with a double-stranded DNA virus. Which of the following conditions is also commonly associated with this viral infection?
options: (A) Gastroenteritis (B) Painful dermatomal vesicles (C) Lymphadenopathy (D) Vesicular rash
outputs:
The patient is a 5-year-old boy who presents with blood in his urine, difficulty passing urine, lower abdominal pain, and a burning sensation while urinating. The urinalysis shows RBCs, WBCs, and casts. The pediatrician believes the boy has a bladder infection with a double-stranded DNA virus. This is most likely a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by enterovirus. Enterovirus is a double-stranded RNA virus that can cause UTIs in children. It is also commonly associated with gastroenteritis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 47-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension presents to the emergency department with severe left knee pain. She has been experiencing worsening pain over the past week and has noticed increased swelling and erythema over the past 2 days. She denies any recent trauma or injuries. She is currently taking hydroxychloroquine and celecoxib. On examination, her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and erythema over the left knee, with moderate effusion. The patient has difficulty moving the knee due to pain. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Arrange for an urgent MRI of the knee (B) Administer intravenous vancomycin (C) Administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole (D) Arrange for an urgent arthrocentesis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. She presents with severe left knee pain, swelling, and erythema. She denies any recent trauma or injuries. The patient has difficulty moving the knee due to pain. The most likely diagnosis is a knee effusion secondary to rheumatoid arthritis. The next step in management would be to arrange for an urgent arthrocentesis to drain the effusion and relieve the patient's pain. The answer is (D).

She has moderate swelling over the left knee, with mild localized warmth, and moderate pain with flexion and extension of the knee. There is no effusion. (A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 46-year-old woman presents with difficulty initiating sleep, as well as frequent nighttime awakenings. She reports making multiple mistakes at her office job, has an inability to concentrate, and feels sleepy throughout the day. She is worried that her sleeping troubles will cause her to get fired. Which of the following would best treat this patient’s insomnia pharmacologically?
(A) Chlordiazepoxide (B) Triazolam (C) Diazepam (D) Modafinil
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 46-year-old woman presents with difficulty initiating sleep, as well as frequent nighttime awakenings. She reports making multiple mistakes at her office job, has an inability to concentrate, and feels sleepy throughout the day. She is worried that her sleeping troubles will cause her to get fired. Which of the following would best treat this patient’s insomnia pharmacologically?
options: (A) Chlordiazepoxide (B) Triazolam (C) Diazepam (D) Modafinil
outputs:
The patient has difficulty initiating sleep, frequent nighttime awakenings, and daytime sleepiness. She is worried that her sleeping troubles will cause her to get fired. The patient has symptoms of insomnia. Chlordiazepoxide and triazolam are both benzodiazepines that can treat insomnia. However, benzodiazepines have a high potential for abuse and dependence. Diazepam is also a benzodiazepine and is not recommended for long-term use. Modafinil is a medication that promotes wakefulness and is used to treat conditions like narcolepsy, obstructive sleep apnea, and shift work sleep disorder. It is not recommended for insomnia. The best option to treat this patient's insomnia pharmacologically would be chlordiazepoxide. The answer is (A).

Q: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of sudden hearing loss, dizziness, and nausea. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. He appears uncomfortable and is sweating. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a Weber Class III/IV systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a 2+ pitting edema at the ankles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer aspirin (B) Administer nitroglycerin (C) Administer furosemide (D) Administer captopril
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking. He appears uncomfortable and is sweating. His blood pressure is elevated at 180/110 mm Hg. He has sudden hearing loss, dizziness, and nausea. These are symptoms of a hypertensive emergency. The patient needs immediate treatment to lower his blood pressure. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer nitroglycerin. Nitroglycerin is a medication that dilates blood vessels and lowers blood pressure. The answer is (B).

Q: A 71-year-old man with a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia is brought to the emergency department by his family because of a 2-day history of worsening confusion, agitation, and inability to recognize family members. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a large, firm, and nodular prostate. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 1+ blood. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Acute renal failure (B) Acute interstitial nephritis (C) Urinary tract infection (D) Hyponatremia
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He is brought to the emergency department by his family because of a 2-day history of worsening confusion, agitation, and inability to recognize family members. His blood pressure is elevated at 160/90 mm Hg. He has a large, firm, and nodular prostate. The patient has symptoms of acute urinary retention. The patient has a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy, which is a risk factor for urinary retention. The patient's urinalysis shows 2+ protein and 1+ blood, which could be caused by acute urinary retention. The most likely diagnosis is acute urinary retention. The answer is (C).

Q: A 5-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician for evaluation of difficulties noted at school. Her kindergarten teacher voiced her concern that the child ‘spaces out’ often and thinks she may have ADHD. The parents deny any history of head trauma or infection. Her blood pressure is 106/74 mm Hg, the heart rate is 69/min, and the respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical exam demonstrates a happy child who has reached developmental milestones. Laboratory results are within normal limits. EEG demonstrates a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern (see image). The decision is made to start the child on medical therapy. What should be advised to the parents as a potential side effect of the first-line medication?
(A) Nystagmus (B) GI upset (C) Facial rash and blood in the urine (D) Weight gain and change in hair color
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 5-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician for evaluation of difficulties noted at school. Her kindergarten teacher voiced her concern that the child ‘spaces out’ often and thinks she may have ADHD. The parents deny any history of head trauma or infection. Her blood pressure is 106/74 mm Hg, the heart rate is 69/min, and the respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical exam demonstrates a happy child who has reached developmental milestones. Laboratory results are within normal limits. EEG demonstrates a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern (see image). The decision is made to start the child on medical therapy. What should be advised to the parents as a potential side effect of the first-line medication?
options: (A) Nystagmus (B) GI upset (C) Facial rash and blood in the urine (D) Weight gain and change in hair color
outputs:
The patient is a 5-year-old girl who is being evaluated for ADHD. The EEG demonstrates a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern, which is consistent with absence epilepsy. The decision is made to start the child on medical therapy. The first-line medication for absence epilepsy is ethosuximide. A potential side effect of ethosuximide is GI upset, including nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. The answer is (B).

Q: A 16-year-old boy comes to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss and severe headache over the past 2 hours. He has no history of ear trauma or previous hearing loss. He has been healthy otherwise. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a Weber Class III/IV systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. The rest of the examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous antibiotics (B) Order a CT scan of the head (C) Order an MRI of the inner ear (D) Refer to an otolaryngologist
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden hearing loss and a severe headache. He has no history of ear trauma or previous hearing loss. The patient appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a Weber Class III/IV systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border. This murmur is consistent with a congenital heart defect. The most appropriate next step in management is to refer the patient to an otolaryngologist for further evaluation and management of the hearing loss. The answer is (D).

Q: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, chills, and a 10-pound weight loss. She has had no recent travel or sick contacts. She has been healthy otherwise. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple, tender, and swollen lymph nodes in the neck, axillae, and groin. The liver and spleen are not enlarged. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's white blood cell count is 18,000/mm3, with 80% lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous antibiotics (B) Order a CT scan of the head and neck (C) Order a PET scan (D) Refer to an infectious disease specialist
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 1-week history of fever, chills, and a 10-pound weight loss. She has had no recent travel or sick contacts. She has been healthy otherwise. Examination shows multiple, tender, and swollen lymph nodes in the neck, axillae, and groin. The liver and spleen are not enlarged. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's white blood cell count is 18,000/mm3, with 80% lymphocytes. This suggests that the patient has lymphadenitis, which is an infection of the lymph nodes. The most appropriate next step in management is to refer the patient to an infectious disease specialist for further evaluation and management of the infection. The answer is (D).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. (A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Tricuspid valve stenosis (B) Mitral valve prolapse (C) Mitral valve stenosis (D) Aortic valve stenosis
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: (A) Tricuspid valve stenosis (B) Mitral valve prolapse (C) Mitral valve stenosis (D) Aortic valve stenosis
outputs: The patient has a history of smoking and hypertension, which are both risk factors for cardiovascular disease. He presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue, which could be symptoms of heart failure. The physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses, which could be due to decreased cardiac output. The cardiac examination shows a cardiac murmur, which could be due to a valvular heart disease. The most likely diagnosis is aortic valve stenosis. Aortic valve stenosis is a narrowing of the exit of the left ventricle of the heart (where the aorta begins), such a narrowing reduces blood flow into the aorta. This reduction in blood flow reduces the amount of blood that reaches the body. This reduction in blood flow to the body results in fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath. The answer is (D).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

question: Q: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after a temporal artery biopsy was performed to evaluate headache and blurry vision. He has a 12-year history of hypertension treated with lisinopril. Results of the testing show decreased concentrations of arginine in vascular endothelial cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
options: (A) Increased binding of calcium to calmodulin (B) Increased phosphorylation of myosin (C) Increased production of nitric oxide (D) Decreased concentration of bradykinin
outputs:
The patient has a history of hypertension and is being treated with lisinopril. He has a 12-year history of hypertension. He has been experiencing headaches and blurry vision. The temporal artery biopsy showed decreased concentrations of arginine in vascular endothelial cells. The most likely explanation for this finding is decreased concentration of bradykinin. Bradykinin is a potent vasodilator that causes the release of nitric oxide, which leads to increased blood flow and decreased blood pressure. The answer is (D).

Q: A 60-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe back pain. She has a history of breast cancer treated with mastectomy and chemotherapy 10 years ago. She has been healthy since then. She has no prior history of back pain. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's electrolyte levels, liver function tests, and renal function tests are within normal limits. The patient's blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are 20 mg/dL and 1.2 mg/dL, respectively. Urinalysis shows 2+ proteinuria. The patient's chest x-ray shows a prominent aortic arch. ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform computed tomography angiography (B) Perform ultrasound of the abdomen (C) Perform radionuclide imaging (D) Administer intravenous furosemide
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of breast cancer treated with mastectomy and chemotherapy 10 years ago. She has been healthy since then. She has no prior history of back pain. She appears uncomfortable. The patient's blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are 20 mg/dL and 1.2 mg/dL, respectively, indicating that there is a renal impairment. The patient's chest x-ray shows a prominent aortic arch. The most likely explanation for this finding is that the patient has an abdominal aortic aneurysm. This is consistent with the patient's sudden onset of severe back pain. The answer is (A).

The most likely explanation for this finding is that the patient has a knee infection. This is consistent with the patient's swollen and warm left knee. The answer is (A).

Q: While traveling abroad a physician is asked to attend a meeting regarding healthcare in the region. The rate of chlamydial infection is exceptionally high in the area, and the local government is wanting to test a new treatment for these infections. To test the new therapy, the physician is asked to oversee the operations of testing this new treatment. When asking what this would entail, the officials tell the physician that they plan to infect the local prison population with chlamydia and then test the new treatment on these individuals. Which of the following is the best response from the physician?
(A) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of autonomy.” (B) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of justice.” (C) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of nonmaleficence.” (D) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of beneficence.”
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: While traveling abroad a physician is asked to attend a meeting regarding healthcare in the region. The rate of chlamydial infection is exceptionally high in the area, and the local government is wanting to test a new treatment for these infections. To test the new therapy, the physician is asked to oversee the operations of testing this new treatment. When asking what this would entail, the officials tell the physician that they plan to infect the local prison population with chlamydia and then test the new treatment on these individuals. Which of the following is the best response from the physician?
options: (A) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of autonomy.” (B) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of justice.” (C) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of nonmaleficence.” (D) “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of beneficence.”
outputs:
The physician is asked to oversee the operations of testing a new treatment for chlamydial infections in the local prison population. The physician should be aware of the ethical principles that guide medical practice. The ethical principle that is relevant in this scenario is nonmaleficence, which states that physicians should not cause harm or injury to their patients. Infecting the local prison population with chlamydia would be intentionally causing harm to the prisoners, which would be unethical. The physician should not participate in this study because it goes against the ethical principle of nonmaleficence. The answer is (C).

Q: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of fatigue, malaise, and myalgias. She also reports intermittent arthralgias, headaches, and nausea. She has a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 20 years and has a 10-year history of stable hypertension that is well-controlled with medication. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood cell count shows a hemoglobin of 12.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of 7,500/mm3, and platelet count of 250,000/mm3. Serum electrolyte levels, liver function tests, and thyroid function tests are within normal limits. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) and double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibody are positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Systemic lupus erythematosus (B) Rheumatoid arthritis (C) Hypertensive crisis (D) Chronic fatigue syndrome
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 6-month history of fatigue, malaise, and myalgias, as well as intermittent arthralgias, headaches, and nausea. She has a history of smoking and stable hypertension that is well-controlled with medication. Her physical examination and laboratory test results are unremarkable. However, her ANA and anti-dsDNA antibody are positive, which suggests an autoimmune disorder. The most likely diagnosis is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, malaise, myalgias, arthralgias, headaches, and nausea. The presence of positive ANA and anti-dsDNA antibody supports the diagnosis of SLE. The answer is (A).

Q: A 75-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents with a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. He denies any recent trauma or injury. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order radiographs of the knee (B) Order an MRI of the knee (C) Initiate treatment with intravenous antibiotics (D) Arrange for orthopedic surgical consultation

He appears uncomfortable, and physical examination shows swelling and erythema of the left knee. The patient is unable to fully extend the knee. The most likely diagnosis is a septic knee effusion. The patient's age and history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia increase the likelihood of a septic joint. Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. She has a history of asthma and has frequent exacerbations despite receiving maximal medical therapy. Physical examination shows scattered expiratory wheezing. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 9,800/mm3 (13% eosinophils) and elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E. An x-ray of the chest shows thickened bronchial walls and perihilar opacities. Sputum culture shows scattered septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees. Which of the following is most likely to be increased in this patient?
(A) IL-28 (B) TGF-β (C) IFN-α (D) IL-4
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. She has a history of asthma and has frequent exacerbations despite receiving maximal medical therapy. Physical examination shows scattered expiratory wheezing. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 9,800/mm3 (13% eosinophils) and elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E. An x-ray of the chest shows thickened bronchial walls and perihilar opacities. Sputum culture shows scattered septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees. Which of the following is most likely to be increased in this patient?
options: (A) IL-28 (B) TGF-β (C) IFN-α (D) IL-4
outputs:
The patient has a history of asthma and has frequent exacerbations despite receiving maximal medical therapy. She has progressively worsening shortness of breath, scattered expiratory wheezing, elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E, and a chest x-ray that shows thickened bronchial walls and perihilar opacities. Sputum culture shows scattered septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees. This is consistent with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). ABPA is a condition in which Aspergillus causes airway inflammation and bronchospasm in patients with a history of asthma or cystic fibrosis. The most likely answer is (D) IL-4. IL-4 is a cytokine that promotes the growth and activation of eosinophils, which are increased in the patient's leukocyte count (13% eosinophils). IL-4 is also associated with the pathogenesis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. The answer is (D).

Q: A 42-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss in his right ear. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. He has no ear pain or discharge. He appears anxious. Physical examination shows Weber Class III/IV hearing loss in the right ear. Otoscopic examination shows a Weber Class III/IV hearing loss in the right ear. There is no evidence of cerumen impaction or otitis externa. The patient is currently taking no medications. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous furosemide (B) Administer intravenous hydralazine (C) Administer intravenous prednisone (D) Refer the patient to an otolaryngologist for further evaluation
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking. He presents with sudden hearing loss in his right ear. There is no evidence of cerumen impaction or otitis externa. The patient has no ear pain or discharge. The most likely diagnosis is sudden sensorineural hearing loss. This is an otologic emergency that requires prompt medical attention. The most appropriate next step in management is to refer the patient to an otolaryngologist for further evaluation. The answer is (D).

Q: A 29-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. She has no history of previous neurological events. She is currently taking no medications. On examination, she is able to speak in short, broken sentences and has left-sided hemiparesis. The rest of the neurological examination is normal. The patient has a history of hypertension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous furosemide (B) Administer intravenous hydralazine (C) Administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) (D) Refer the patient to a neurologist for further evaluation
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension. She presents with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. She has no history of previous neurological events. The most likely diagnosis is acute ischemic stroke. This is a neurological emergency that requires prompt medical attention. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). tPA is a thrombolytic agent that is effective in treating acute ischemic stroke. The answer is (C).

Q: A 29-year-old G1P0 female presents at 22 weeks gestation for her first prenatal care appointment. Physical exam demonstrates a uterine size greater than expected for her gestational age and taut, shiny skin with scattered striae on her abdomen. Ultrasound examination of the fetus reveals 2.5 L of amniotic fluid (normal 1.5-2.0 L) with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 34 (normal AFI 20-25). Which of the following fetal abnormalities or dysfunctions could have contributed to these abnormal ultrasound findings?
(A) Renal agenesis (B) Pulmonary hypoplasia (C) Duodenal atresia (D) Posterior urethral valve
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 29-year-old G1P0 female presents at 22 weeks gestation for her first prenatal care appointment. Physical exam demonstrates a uterine size greater than expected for her gestational age and taut, shiny skin with scattered striae on her abdomen. Ultrasound examination of the fetus reveals 2.5 L of amniotic fluid (normal 1.5-2.0 L) with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 34 (normal AFI 20-25). Which of the following fetal abnormalities or dysfunctions could have contributed to these abnormal ultrasound findings?
options: (A) Renal agenesis (B) Pulmonary hypoplasia (C) Duodenal atresia (D) Posterior urethral valve
outputs:
The patient is a 29-year-old G1P0 female who presents at 22 weeks gestation for her first prenatal care appointment. Physical exam demonstrates a uterine size greater than expected for her gestational age and taut, shiny skin with scattered striae on her abdomen. Ultrasound examination of the fetus reveals 2.5 L of amniotic fluid (normal 1.5-2.0 L) with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 34 (normal AFI 20-25). This could be due to a condition that causes excessive amniotic fluid production. The most likely diagnosis is posterior urethral valve (PUV). PUV is a congenital obstruction of the urethra that occurs in male fetuses and is caused by a failure of the urethral folds to canalize properly during fetal development. PUV can cause excessive amniotic fluid production and is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections, hydronephrosis, and bladder stones. The other options (renal agenesis, pulmonary hypoplasia, and duodenal atresia) can also cause abnormal ultrasound findings, but they are less likely given the patient's symptoms and ultrasound findings. The answer is (D).

Q: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-week history of worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has no vaginal bleeding or discharge. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She has no medical or surgical history. On physical examination, her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min. Abdominal examination shows localized tenderness to palpation over the right lower quadrant of the abdomen with no rebound tenderness or guarding. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Pelvic ultrasound (B) Intravenous pyelography (C) CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast (D) Laparoscopy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-week history of worsening right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She has no vaginal bleeding or discharge. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She has no medical or surgical history. On physical examination, her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min. Abdominal examination shows localized tenderness to palpation over the right lower quadrant of the abdomen with no rebound tenderness or guarding. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with acute appendicitis. The most appropriate next step in management is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast. A CT scan can help confirm the diagnosis of appendicitis and identify any potential complications, such as an appendiceal mass or abscess. The answer is (C).

The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with chest pain. She reports sudden severe and crushing substernal chest pain that started 1 hour ago. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and a prior myocardial infarction requiring a coronary artery bypass graft 2 years ago. She takes aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, spironolactone, atorvastatin, and insulin. She is retired and lives a sedentary lifestyle at home. Her temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 109/68 mmHg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 24/min. Before being able to start the physical examination, the patient loses consciousness. Her pulse is palpable but weak. Her blood pressure is now 88/50 mmHg and pulse is 130/min. Her skin is pale, cold, and clammy. An electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I, aVL, V3, V4, V5, and V6. A medication that primarily stimulates which of the following receptors would be most appropriate to improve the hemodynamic status of this patient?
(A) Alpha-2 adrenergic receptor (B) Beta-1 adrenergic receptor (C) Beta-2 adrenergic receptor (D) D2 receptor
A: Let's think step by step.

options: (A) Alpha-2 adrenergic receptor (B) Beta-1 adrenergic receptor (C) Beta-2 adrenergic receptor (D) D2 receptor
outputs:
The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and a prior myocardial infarction requiring a coronary artery bypass graft 2 years ago. She takes aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, spironolactone, atorvastatin, and insulin. The patient presents with sudden severe and crushing substernal chest pain. The patient lost consciousness. This will increase the patient's heart rate and blood pressure, improving the hemodynamic status. The answer is (B).

Q: A 42-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 1-month history of a painless, firm, and mobile 4 cm x 3 cm mass in the right breast. She also reports having had a nipple discharge for 1 week. Her past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. Her current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She has no significant family history. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/88 mmHg. Physical examination shows a firm, mobile, and nontender mass in the right breast. The mass is not adherent to the skin or underlying tissue. The nipple-areola complex is normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A mammogram shows a round, circumscribed, and homogeneous mass in the right breast. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Benign breast tumor (B) Invasive ductal carcinoma (C) Invasive lobular carcinoma (D) Fibroadenoma
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a painless, firm, and mobile 4 cm x 3 cm mass in the right breast. She also reports having had a nipple discharge for 1 week. Her past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. Her current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. She has no significant family history. Physical examination shows a firm, mobile, and nontender mass in the right breast. The mass is not adherent to the skin or underlying tissue. The nipple-areola complex is normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A mammogram shows a round, circumscribed, and homogeneous mass in the right breast. The patient has no significant family history. The most likely diagnosis is a benign breast tumor. The answer is (A).

Q: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. He also reports sudden onset of difficulty speaking and difficulty walking. His past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. His current medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He has no significant family history.
